comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: Likely the wife and children of David Franklin Houston, "academic, businessman and politician."

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: David Franklin Houston married Texas-born Helen Beall (1873-1940) in 1895. Here's her tombstone in New York: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=66436070 They had five children all together, sons Duval, David Jr., and Lawrence, daughters Elizabeth and Helen. Helen Beall Houston wrote an unpublished memoir; her son David typed it up with some additional notes, and donated it to the Herman Brown Free Library in Burnet TX after her death.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: bior and pennylrichardsca: Thanks for providing more information on Houston.  We'll include her full name next time we update.

comment.author: 60934085@N02
comment._content: The above comments are correct; thank you! Helen Beall (b. 1873) in Travis County (Austin) Texas She married David Franklin Houston (b. 1866 in Monroe, Union County, NC) on Dec. 11, 1895. Their first two children, DuVal Beall Houston and Helen Elizabeth Houston died young in Texas. David Franklin Jr. (b. 1898 in Austin, TX) died Feb. 1972 in New York, NY. The middle child above was my mother, Helen Beall Houston (Jr.) b. July 16, 1911 and who died in Los Angeles, CA, in 1996. The baby is Lawrence Reid Houston of Washington, DC, who died in 1998 (see CIA info online). All except Helen Beall Houston, my mother, are buried in Oyster Bay, Long Island, NY.

comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/60934085@N02] Wow, that is very great to hear, finding and successfully identifying such close relatives online. Thank you for letting us know

comment.author: 60934085@N02
comment._content:
Special thanks to my daughter, who found this online, as well! 
 forgot to mention that the photo was probably taken in Washington, D.C, about 1913 during Woodrow Wilson's first year as President. David Franklin Houston, the husband and father not pictured, was Secretary of Agriculture during both terms and also Secretary of the Treasury for 18 months during Wilson's last term.
